conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D and needs to be predicted which container (E, F, or G) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
The board contains ramps of different colors (blue, grey, brown, black) with varying orientations and reservoirs labeled E, F, and G at the bottom.
The blue ramp is near the top and is oriented low-toward the right.
The grey ramp is in the center-right and is oriented low-toward the right.
The brown ramp is in the center-left and is oriented low-toward the right.
The black ramp is at the bottom-right and is oriented low-toward the left.

Streams are first bent rightward by the ramps; if high enough, they can be caught again and bent further right, but the black ramp sends streams back toward the middle and drops them above the brown reservoir.
Liquid from inlet A misses the blue ramp, lands on the brown ramp, is carried far right, lands on the black ramp, and is dumped just left of it into reservoir F.
Liquid from inlet B hits the upper part of the blue ramp, slides right, reaches the grey ramp, slides right again, and falls beyond the black ramp into reservoir G.
Liquid from inlet C lands lower on the blue ramp than B, misses the grey ramp after the first slide, falls sooner, and is caught by the black ramp, which tips it left into reservoir F.
Liquid from inlet D is almost above the grey ramp, follows the same double-right course as B, and ends in reservoir G.
After passing through the baffles, liquids from A and C pour into container F, while those from B and D pour into container G; none of the inlets reaches container E.
